name: Soma
primarySources: Rigveda (entire Mandala IX dedicated to Soma)
uses: Vedic ritual sacrifice (yajna) - pressed and offered to gods
Priestly consumption - drunk by priests during Soma sacrifice
Divine communion - enabled communication with gods
Immortality ritual - believed to confer amrita (immortality)
Purification ceremony - cleansed participants of sin
rituals: Soma Yajna - elaborate Vedic sacrifice lasting multiple days
Agnistoma - fire sacrifice where Soma is central offering
Chanting of Soma hymns from Rigveda Mandala IX
Offering to Indra, Vayu, and other Vedic deities

physical: Stalks or stems (not leaves or fruits)
Crushed between pressing stones to extract juice
Described as brown, tawny, or golden
Juicy when fresh, can be stored when dried
Mixed with milk, curds, or honey before consumption

preparation: Mixed with milk, curds, and/or water
Offerings made at prescribed times during yajna

symbolism.moon: Soma is also the Moon god; the plant's essence is connected to lunar cycles
symbolism.immortality: The pressed juice represents amrita, the nectar of immortality
symbolism.divine_ecstasy: Represents the bliss of communion with the divine
symbolism.purification: The pressing and filtering symbolize spiritual purification

metadata.region: Indian subcontinent, possibly from mountains of Central Asia

description: Soma is the most sacred plant of Vedic religion, a divine intoxicant pressed during elaborate rituals and offered to the gods. The entire ninth mandala of the Rigveda is dedicated to Soma, praising its power to confer immortality, divine vision, and strength. The identity of the original Soma plant remains one of the great mysteries of Indology, with candidates including ephedra, fly agaric mushroom, and various other plants. Beyond the plant, Soma is also a lunar deity who rides a chariot across the night sky.
associatedDeities: Soma/Chandra (Moon god, deity of the plant)

relatedEntities.name: Indra
relatedEntities.relationship: Chief consumer - Soma gives Indra strength for battle

relatedEntities.name: Soma/Chandra
relatedEntities.relationship: Lunar deity associated with the plant

botanicalIdentity.status: Unknown - one of the great mysteries of Indology
candidates: Amanita muscaria (fly agaric mushroom - R.G. Wasson theory)
Various species of Sarcostemma or Periploca
botanicalIdentity.scholarly_debate: The original Soma plant's identity was lost after the Vedic period. Modern substitutes include various Ephedra species and other plants.

name: Tulsi (Holy Basil)

etymology.derivation: Sanskrit tulasƒ´, possibly from tula (balance) indicating its balancing properties

medicinal: Respiratory health - treats coughs and colds
spiritual: Death rituals - placed in mouth of dying

uses: Daily worship (nitya puja) - watered and circumambulated every morning
Tulsi Vivah - ceremonial marriage to Shaligram/Vishnu in Kartik month
Puja offerings - no Vishnu worship complete without Tulsi leaves
Tulsi tea - Ayurvedic adaptogen for stress, immunity, and respiratory health
Sacred tulsi leaves in prasad and tirtha (holy water)
Tulsi mala (prayer beads) for japa meditation
Death rituals - holy basil placed in mouth to ensure salvation
sacredSignificance: Tulsi is the most sacred plant in Hinduism, revered as the earthly manifestation of the goddess Lakshmi and the beloved plant of Lord Vishnu. According to mythology, Vrinda Devi, a devoted wife, was transformed into the Tulsi plant. Every Hindu household maintains a Tulsi plant in a raised planter called a Tulsi Vrindavan, worshipping it daily. No Vishnu puja is complete without Tulsi leaves, and even touching the plant is considered purifying.
preparationMethods: Tulsi tea: 5-7 fresh leaves or 1 tsp dried, steep or simmer 5-10 minutes
Tulsi-honey-ginger remedy: crush leaves, mix with honey and ginger for colds
Tulsi powder (churna): 1/4-1/2 tsp with warm water daily
Fresh leaves: chewed directly in morning for health
Tulsi water: leaves soaked in water overnight, drunk in morning
safetyWarnings: Avoid large medicinal doses during pregnancy
Can lower blood sugar - diabetics should monitor

hindu.usage: Daily worship in household shrine (tulsi vrindavan). Tulsi Vivah festival in Kartik month. Essential puja offering. Death rituals.
hindu.significance: Goddess Lakshmi resides in Tulsi. Purifies home, brings prosperity, ensures spiritual protection. Most beloved plant of Krishna.

ayurvedic.usage: Rasayana (rejuvenative), adaptogen, immune tonic, respiratory support, stress relief
ayurvedic.significance: Balances all three doshas (Vata, Pitta, Kapha). Promotes longevity and spiritual vitality. Called 'Queen of Herbs.'

description: Tulsi (Holy Basil) is the most sacred plant in Hinduism, revered as the earthly manifestation of the goddess Lakshmi and beloved of Lord Vishnu. According to mythology, Vrinda Devi was transformed into this fragrant herb. Every Hindu household maintains a Tulsi plant, worshipping it daily with water, circumambulation, and prayers. In Ayurveda, Tulsi is called the 'Queen of Herbs' for its adaptogenic and healing properties.

symbolism.protection: Wards off evil spirits and negative energies

Kartik worship - special month of Tulsi veneration
Death rituals - Tulsi leaves placed in mouth of dying person

mythsAndLegends.title: The Story of Vrinda Devi
mythsAndLegends.summary: Vrinda was the devoted wife of the demon Jalandhara, whose power depended on her chastity. When Vishnu took Jalandhara's form to break her vow, Vrinda cursed Vishnu to become a stone (Shaligram) and herself became the Tulsi plant. Vishnu blessed Tulsi to be worshipped in all his temples and to be his most beloved.

mythsAndLegends.title: Tulsi Vivah
mythsAndLegends.summary: Each year on Prabodhini Ekadashi (the 11th day of the bright fortnight of Kartik), Hindus ceremonially marry a Tulsi plant to a Shaligram stone or image of Vishnu. This marks the end of the monsoon and the beginning of the Hindu wedding season.
